choices.text: It can cause fissures at the corner of the mouth, pruritis and alopecia
An infant with preference for carrots and butternut squash can develop toxicity
Symptoms subsides with withdrawal of source

questions.text: Which of the following statements about vitamin A toxicity is false?
questions.solution:
• Signs of subacute or chronic toxicity can include
    • Headache, vomiting, anorexia
    • dry, itchy desquamating skin
    • fissuring at the corners of the mouth
    • alopecia and/ or coarsening of the hair
    • swelling of the bones
    • enlargement of the liver and spleen
    • diplopia, increased intracranial pressure, irritability, stupor
    • desquamation of the palms and the soles of the feet.
  • Radiographs may show hyperostosis affecting several long bones, especially in the middle of the shafts.
  • Symptoms may subside rapidly on withdrawal of the vitamin, but the rate of improvement depends on the amount of vitamin A that has built up in tissues.
  • In young children, toxicity is associated with vomiting and bulging fontanels.
  • Acute hypervitaminosis A, such as after consumption of a single large (30-60 mg dose) of vitamin A may include nausea, vomiting, and drowsiness; less-common symptoms include diplopia, papilledema, cranial nerve palsies, and other symptoms suggesting pseudotumor cerebri.
  • A syndrome of severe congenital malformations may occur in infants of mothers who have consumed therapeutic doses (0.5-1.5 mg/kg) of oral 13-cis-retinoic acid (e.g., Accutane), generally taken for the treatment of acne or cancer, during the 1st trimester of pregnancy.
  • Excessive intake of carotenoids is not associated with toxicity but can cause yellow coloration of the skin that disappears when intake is reduced; this disorder (carotenemia) is especially likely to occur in children with liver disease, diabetes mellitus, or hypothyroidism and in those who do not have enzymes that metabolize carotenoids.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated feature with zinc deficiency?
questions.solution:
Symptoms associated with zinc deficiency are:

  • Decreased growth
  • Dermatitis of extremities and around orifices
  • Impaired immunity
  • Poor wound healing
  • Hypogonadism
  • Diarrhea

questions.text: For children <5 years, the highest global prevalence of micronutrient and trace elements deficiencies is that of?
questions.solution: • For children <5 years, the global prevalence is estimated to be 33% for vitamin A deficiency, 29% for iodine deficiency, 17% for zinc deficiency, and 18% for iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: Classical triad of Wernicke encephalopathy of thiamine deficiency is characterized by?
questions.solution:
Thiamine deficiency

  • Early symptoms of thiamine deficiency are nonspecific, such as fatigue, apathy, irritability, depression, drowsiness, poor mental concentration, anorexia, nausea, and abdominal discomfort.

As the condition progresses, more-specific manifestations of beriberi:

  • Peripheral neuritis (manifesting as tingling, burning, paresthesia of the toes and feet)
  • Decreased deep tendon reflexes
  • loss of vibration sense
  • tenderness and cramping of the leg muscles,
  • heart failure
  • psychological disturbances
  • ptosis of the eyelids and atrophy of the optic nerve.
  • Hoarseness or aphonia caused by paralysis of the laryngeal nerve is a characteristic sign.
  • Muscle atrophy and tenderness of the nerve trunks are followed by ataxia, loss of coordination,

Later signs

  • Increased intracranial pressure
  • Meningismus,
  • Coma.

The classic clinical triad of Wernicke encephalopathy

  • mental status changes,
  • ocular signs,
  • ataxia

questions.text: Which of the following is not an important mechanism for maintaining vitamin B12 levels?
questions.solution:
• Intrinsic factors get bound to the cobalamin in the duodenum and gets transported to the ileum.
  • From the distal ileum, under alkaline conditions, the cobalamin is internalized in to the enterocytes and transported through the Transcobalamin.
  • Overgrowth of bacteria in the small bowel can reduce the B12 absorption as they consume the vitamin or they disintegrate the cobalamin from the intrinsic factor.

choices.text: Ground glass appearance of shafts of long bones
Pencil outlining of epiphysis and diaphysis

questions.text: Which of the following radiological finding is the most specific for Scurvy?
questions.solution:
The more specific but late radiologic feature of scurvy is a zone of rarefaction under the white line at the metaphysis. is zone of rarefaction (Trummerfeld zone), a linear break in the bone that is proximal and parallel to the white line, represents area of debris of broken-down bone trabeculae and connective tissue.

RADIOLOGICAL FINDINGS OF SCURVY- VERY IMPORTANT - MUST KNOW ALL POINTS

questions.text: When suspecting vitamin C deficiency in a child, which of the following test is the best indicator of Vitamin C levels?
questions.solution:
• Plasma ascorbate levels are convenient for diagnosis.
  • Leukocyte ascorbate levels are better indicator of body stores but are difficult to perform.
  • Urinary ascorbate levels can be measured after an oral load of vitamin.
  • Plasma amino acid levels are normal in vitamin C-deficient individuals.
  • Hence, out of all the methods, best for diagnosis is leukocyte ascorbate level and convenient and commonly used is plasma ascorbate level.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statement/s about Vitamin C and Scurvy
A. It is a heat labile vitamin
B. Exclusive breastfeeding can cause scurvy in infancy
C. Therapeutic dose of vitamin C is 100-200mg/day
D. Vitamin C is predominantly stored in Liver
questions.solution:
• Vitamin C supplements of 100-200 mg/day orally or parenterally ensure rapid and complete cure of Scurvy. The treatment should be continued for up to 3 months for complete recovery.
  • Breastfeeding protects against vitamin C deficiency throughout infancy. In children consuming milk formula, fortification with vitamin C must be ensured.
  • Children consuming heat-treated milk should consume adequate vitamin C-rich foods in infancy. Vitamin C is easily destroyed by prolonged storage, overcooking, and processing of foods.
  • Vitamin C is not stored in the body but is taken up by all tissues; the highest levels are found in the pituitary and adrenal glands.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following vitamins is associated with increased risk of thrombosis?
questions.solution:
• Deficiency in vitamin E is associated with an increased risk of thrombosis, particularly in neonates, due to its role in platelet aggregation.
  • Vitamin K deficiency leads to hemorrhagic disorders, since vitamin K is essential in the production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X, and proteins C and S.
  • Increased bruising can be seen in vitamin C deficiency due to an inability to synthesize collagen.
  • Vitamins A is not associated with either an increased bleeding or thrombosis risk.

choices.text: A 4 day old baby of a healthy mother started on immediate breast feeding
A 2 year old who spent 21 days in NICU on total parenteral nutrition
A 1 year old with cystic fibrosis missed during early infancy
A 1 year old with prolonged history of diarrhea and multiple antibiotics therapy

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is the child least likely to suffer from vitamin K deficiency?
questions.solution:
Causes of Vitamin K deficiency are:

  • Occult malabsorption of vitamin K,
    • Undiagnosed cystic fibrosis or cholestatic liver disease (e.g., biliary atresia, α1-antitrypsin deficiency).
    • Secondary to maternal intake of medications (warfarin, phenobarbital, phenytoin)
  • Result of fat malabsorption
    • Cholestatic liver disease
    • Pancreatic disease,
    • Intestinal disorders (celiac sprue, inflammatory bowel disease, short-bowel syndrome).
  • Prolonged diarrhea can cause vitamin K deficiency, especially in breastfed infants. Age.
  • Use of broad-spectrum antibiotics that eliminate the intestine's vitamin K2- producing bacteria can cause vitamin K deficiency. This scenario is especially common in the intensive care unit.
  • Patients who receive total parenteral nutrition without vitamin K supplementation.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin is the most important for free radical scavenging action?
questions.solution:
• Out of all the options, Vitamin A, C and E have antioxidant property. Out of these, Vitamin E is the most important.
  • It is mainly located within the cell membranes, preventing lipid peroxidation and formation of free radicals.
  • Deficiency of vitamin E can cause, hemolysis and neurological symptoms especially in the posterior column.

questions.text: What is the dose of vitamin A supplement given to babies along with Measles vaccine at 9 months of age?
questions.solution:
• Children are given supplemental dose of Vitamin A every 6 monthly starting from age of 9 months.
  • <12 months- 1,00,000 IU
  • >12 months- 2,00,000 IU every 6 monthly till 5 years of age.
